course.subject: ECON
course.name: Green Finance and Sustainability
course.description: This course discusses the application of finance in addressing contemporary environmental issues, such as pollution and climate change. Topics include the fundamental theories of environmental economics, strategies for a green economy and sustainable business, as well as related legislative and regulatory frameworks. The course also covers cases regarding the environmental impacts on asset prices, such as real estate prices and stock market performance, and discusses the challenges in public finance in the setting of sustainability. Students will learn basic financial tools to navigate environmental risks as an investor, an asset manager, or a regulator.
course.prerequisites: ECON 3113 OR ECON 3014

reviews.author: cAtInAboTtle
reviews.comment_content: This course introduces the key concepts of environmental economics and discusses theoretical models for different market strategies related to environmental regulations, such as emissions taxes, regulatory standards, and subsidies. We also had a guest lecture from the Hong Kong Green Finance Association to share career insights. If you are interested in ESG or green finance, you can also choose to focus your group projects on these topics too.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Rao is a nice guy, willing to discuss with students and answer questions patiently. He also asks for students' feedback to improve course materials accordingly. Also one of the few professors who provide feedback on group reports and presentations.
reviews.comment_grading:
1. Two Homework 20%
2. Midterm 30%
3. Class participation 15%
4. Group project 35%
One of the following topics:
- a trading pitch (on a stock, a bond, or a trading strategy) with a specific focus on their sustainability (”green”) aspects;
– a report on the current developments of a regional green finance market;
– an evaluation of an environmental policy.

Grading is really good!
reviews.comment_workload: Light workload. Only two assignments throughout the whole semester and no final exam.
